deliberation: Checked for metaphors, idioms, personification. The narrative dating is literal. The phrase “to inquire of YHWH” is a conventional cultic idiom, since they are physically inquiring of a prophet, not literally interrogating God face to face.

instances.english_text: to inquire of GOD
target: seeking a prophetic/oracular answer through Ezekiel
ground: seeking guidance and an authoritative response
posture: conventional covenant idiom for prophetic consultation
instances.explanation: The elders come to Ezekiel, but the act is described as ‘inquiring of YHWH,’ using an idiom and metonymy (YHWH for His revealed will through the prophet).

deliberation: Looked for personification and metonymy. The expression that the ‘word of YHWH came’ treats the divine word as an agent that moves; this standard prophetic formula is figurative.

instances.english_text: And the word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a ‘word’ that travels and arrives like a messenger
ground: initiative belongs to God; Ezekiel passively receives
the message approaches him from outside
posture: prophetic formula portraying revelation as a dynamic event
instances.explanation: The ‘word’ is personified as coming to Ezekiel, a metaphorical way of speaking about divine revelation and a metonymy for God’s speech.

deliberation: Checked ‘ben-adam,’ ‘to inquire of me,’ and ‘as I live.’ The main figurative element is the oath formula ‘as I live,’ an idiomatic self-imprecation rather than a literal comment on God’s existence.

instances.english_text: As I live
target: the solemn certainty of God’s refusal to be consulted
vehicle: appeal to one’s own life as guarantee
ground: strengthening the assertion by invoking what is most certain
posture: oath idiom used to heighten seriousness
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘As I live’ is an idiomatic divine oath, not a literal statement about existence, intensifying the resolve not to be inquired of.

deliberation: Considered ‘judge’ language and ‘abominations.’ The verse is forensic and literal: Ezekiel is told to judge and to make them know their fathers’ abominations. No clear metaphor or idiom beyond standard legal terminology.
Looked at ‘chose Israel,’ ‘lifted my hand,’ and ‘made myself known.’ The act of ‘lifting my hand’ is a gesture-metonymy/idiom for swearing an oath.

instances.english_text: I gave My oath to the stock of the House of Jacob (lit. ‘I lifted my hand’)
target: God’s act of swearing a covenantal promise
vehicle: raising one’s hand in a solemn gesture
ground: visible gesture representing an internal pledge
posture: conventional anthropomorphic idiom for divine oath
instances.explanation: ‘Lifting the hand’ is a physical gesture used metonymically and idiomatically to denote taking an oath.

deliberation: Two expressions are figurative: again ‘lifting my hand’ for swearing, and ‘a land flowing with milk and honey,’ a stock metaphor/hyperbole for extraordinary fertility and prosperity.

instances.hebrew_text: נָשָׂ֤אתִי יָדִי֙ לָהֶ֔ם לְהוֹצִיאָ֖ם מֵאֶ֣רֶץ מִצְרָ֑יִם
instances.english_text: that same day I swore to them (lit. ‘I lifted my hand to them’) to take them out of the land of Egypt
target: God’s promise to bring Israel out of Egypt
vehicle: hand-lifting gesture as in human oath ceremonies
instances.explanation: The ‘lifting of the hand’ functions as an idiomatic metonymy for a sworn divine oath.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶל־אֶ֜רֶץ אֲשֶׁר־תַּ֣רְתִּי לָהֶ֗ם זָבַ֤ת חָלָב֙ וּדְבַ֔שׁ צְבִ֥י הִ֖יא לְכׇל־הָאֲרָצֽוֹת
instances.english_text: into a land flowing with milk and honey, the fairest of all lands
target: the goodness and abundance of the promised land
vehicle: a land literally gushing with milk and honey, surpassing all others
instances.explanation: The land is metaphorically depicted as ‘flowing with milk and honey,’ a hyperbolic idiom for great fertility and prosperity.

deliberation: Noted ‘detestable things of their eyes’ and ‘do not defile yourselves.’ The first is a metonymy for idols desired by sight. ‘Defile’ is a purity metaphor extended to moral/idolatrous behavior.

instances.english_text: Cast away, every one of you, the detestable things that you are drawn to (lit. ‘the detestable things of his eyes’)
ground: what they eagerly look at and desire
posture: condemning their visually-driven attachment to idols
instances.explanation: ‘Detestable things of his eyes’ uses the eye metonymically for what one looks at with desire, referring to idols and images.

instances.english_text: do not defile yourselves with the fetishes of Egypt
target: Israel’s moral and cultic corruption through idolatry
vehicle: ritual impurity/defilement associated with contact with unclean things
ground: idolatry makes them unfit for God’s presence like impurity makes one unfit for the sanctuary
posture: using purity-impurity metaphor for spiritual unfaithfulness
instances.explanation: The verb ‘defile yourselves’ extends the ritual purity system metaphorically to ethical-religious behavior, treating idolatry as contaminating filth.

deliberation: Considered expressions of anger. The key figurative phrase is ‘to pour out my fury,’ treating divine wrath as a liquid that can be spilled out onto people.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֹמַ֞ר לִשְׁפֹּ֧ךְ חֲמָתִ֣י עֲלֵיהֶ֗ם לְכַלּ֤וֹת אַפִּי֙ בָּהֶ֔ם
instances.english_text: Then I resolved to pour out My fury upon them, to vent all My anger upon them
target: God’s execution of judgment on Israel
vehicle: liquid being poured out until finished
ground: wrath can inundate and overwhelm like a poured liquid
completeness and intensity of the outpouring
instances.explanation: God’s anger is pictured as a liquid ‘poured out’ to completion, conveying total and overwhelming judgment.

deliberation: Looked at ‘for the sake of My name’ and ‘in the sight/eyes of the nations.’ The main figurative element is ‘My name’ as metonymy for God’s reputation and public honor.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאַ֙עַשׂ֙ לְמַ֣עַן שְׁמִ֔י לְבִלְתִּ֥י הֵחֵ֛ל לְעֵינֵ֥י הַגּוֹיִ֖ם
instances.english_text: But I acted for the sake of My name, that it might not be profaned in the sight of the nations
target: God’s public honor and reputation among the nations
vehicle: ‘name’ as a person’s public identity and reputation
ground: profaning the reputation is like profaning the ‘name’
the name stands for the person’s perceived character
instances.explanation: ‘My name’ stands metonymically for God’s reputation; He acts to protect His honor before the nations.

deliberation: Describes the exodus and entry into the wilderness in straightforward historical terms without clear figurative extensions in this verse alone.

Examined ‘which if a human does, he shall live by them.’ Though ‘live’ can carry theological fullness, here it can be taken literally (life/prosperity) in covenant terms. No explicit image vehicle; treated as literal within covenant-legal idiom.
Considered whether ‘sabbaths as a sign’ is figurative; in covenant-legal discourse ‘sign’ is an actual instituted marker, not a metaphor. No clear metaphor or personification in this verse.
Looked at ‘profaned my sabbaths very much’ and ‘pour out my fury.’ Profaning sabbaths is literal cultic language. The anger expression repeats the ‘pouring out’ metaphor of v.8.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֹמַ֞ר לִשְׁפֹּ֨ךְ חֲמָתִ֧י עֲלֵיהֶ֛ם בַּמִּדְבָּ֖ר לְכַלּוֹתָֽם
instances.english_text: Then I thought to pour out My fury upon them in the wilderness and to make an end of them
target: God’s threatened destruction of Israel in the wilderness
vehicle: liquid forcefully poured out until none remains
instances.explanation: Again divine wrath is imaged as a liquid poured out, emphasizing the devastating and complete nature of the contemplated judgment.

deliberation: Same motif as v.9. ‘For the sake of My name’ is metonymy for concern for God’s public honor.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֶעֱשֶׂ֖ה לְמַ֣עַן שְׁמִ֑י לְבִלְתִּ֤י הֵחֵל֙ לְעֵינֵ֣י הַגּוֹיִ֔ם
instances.english_text: but I acted for the sake of My name, that it might not be profaned in the sight of the nations
vehicle: ‘name’ as representation of person and status
ground: profaning the name equals dishonoring the person
name carries the weight of character
concern for how one is viewed
instances.explanation: Once more ‘My name’ stands for God’s reputation; He acts to prevent His name from being degraded before the nations.

deliberation: We again have ‘I lifted my hand’ (oath idiom) and ‘land flowing with milk and honey’ (fertility metaphor). Both are reused covenantal figures.

instances.english_text: However, I swore to them in the wilderness (lit. ‘I lifted my hand to them’)
target: God’s solemn negative oath not to bring a generation into the land
ground: a visible, solemn sign of commitment
binding oneself to a stated outcome
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘I lifted my hand’ is again idiomatic for swearing an oath, here of exclusion from the land.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶל־הָאָ֣רֶץ אֲשֶׁר־נָתַ֗תִּי זָבַ֤ת חָלָב֙ וּדְבַ֔שׁ צְבִ֥י הִ֖יא לְכׇל־הָאֲרָצֽוֹת
instances.english_text: into the land flowing with milk and honey, the fairest of all lands
target: the extraordinary desirability of the promised land
vehicle: land literally gushing milk and honey, surpassing all others
instances.explanation: The description ‘flowing with milk and honey’ is a vivid, hyperbolic metaphor for exceptional fertility and pleasantness.

deliberation: Key figurative element is the inner life conceptualized as a walking heart: ‘after their fetishes their heart was going.’ Basic path metaphor for desire.

instances.english_text: for their hearts followed after their fetishes (lit. ‘their heart was going after their idols’)
vehicle: a heart/person walking after someone or something
ground: orientation of will and desire towards an object
instances.explanation: The heart is personified as walking after idols, a metaphor for the people’s inner attachment and pursuit of other gods.

deliberation: The phrase ‘my eye spared/pitied them’ is an anthropomorphic idiom: the ‘eye’ stands for God’s compassion and regard.

instances.english_text: But I had pity on them (lit. ‘my eye spared them’)
target: God’s compassionate decision not to destroy Israel
vehicle: an eye that looks with pity and refrains from destroying
ground: seeing someone in distress leads to pity
instances.explanation: God’s ‘eye’ is personified and used metonymically for His compassionate regard, indicating that He refrained from total destruction.

deliberation: Identified the recurrence of the purity metaphor: ‘do not defile yourselves with their fetishes.’ Also ‘walk in the statutes of your fathers’ could be a path metaphor, but here the main clear image is defilement.

instances.english_text: and do not defile yourselves with their fetishes
target: the children’s potential moral-spiritual corruption by idolatry
vehicle: ritual/physical defilement by contact with unclean things
ground: idolatry renders them unfit for relationship with God like impurity bars entry to the sanctuary
instances.explanation: Again, ‘defile yourselves’ frames idolatry in terms of impurity and pollution, using ritual categories metaphorically.

deliberation: The phrase ‘walk in my statutes’ uses the common biblical path metaphor, conceptualizing obedience as walking along a path laid out by God’s laws.

instances.english_text: Follow My laws (lit. ‘walk in My statutes’)
target: Israel’s pattern of conduct in response to God’s commands
vehicle: walking on a path or road
ground: continuous progress and direction over time
choosing a route set by another
instances.explanation: Obedience is cast as ‘walking’ in God’s statutes, a metaphor for shaping one’s life-course by His commands.

deliberation: Sabbaths as a ‘sign’ between God and Israel is covenantal language where the Sabbath functions literally as the ritual marker. No clear additional metaphor beyond that established legal meaning.
Repeated motifs: ‘walk in statutes,’ ‘profane sabbaths,’ and ‘pour out my fury.’ The last again uses the wrath-as-liquid metaphor; here it is the main figurative phrase.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֹמַ֞ר לִשְׁפֹּ֧ךְ חֲמָתִ֣י עֲלֵיהֶ֗ם לְכַלּ֥וֹת אַפִּ֛י בָּ֖ם
instances.english_text: Then I resolved to pour out My fury upon them, to vent all My anger upon them
target: the threatened execution of judgment on the second generation
instances.explanation: God’s fury is again depicted as something poured out, highlighting its intensity and totality.

deliberation: Two idiomatic anthropomorphisms: ‘I turned back My hand’ for restraining action, and ‘for My name’s sake’ for protecting His reputation. Both are distinct figures.

instances.english_text: But I held back My hand
target: God’s decision not to carry out full judgment
vehicle: a human hand pulled back from striking or acting
ground: refraining from an intended action at the last moment
instances.explanation: God’s ‘hand’ symbolizes His power; ‘turning it back’ is an idiomatic way to speak of restraining the execution of wrath.

instances.english_text: and I acted for the sake of My name
target: God’s concern for His public honor before the nations
vehicle: ‘name’ as representation of a person’s fame and honor
ground: harm to the name equals harm to reputation
protecting the name equals upholding honor
instances.explanation: As elsewhere, ‘My name’ is metonymy for God’s reputation, for which He preserves Israel.

deliberation: The phrase ‘I lifted my hand to them in the wilderness to scatter them’ again uses the oath idiom of raised hand. ‘Scatter among the nations’ can be literal exile; focus on the oath figure.

instances.english_text: However, I swore to them in the wilderness (lit. ‘I lifted my hand to them’)
target: God’s solemn declaration to scatter them
vehicle: raised hand gesture as in treaty/oath rituals
ground: external gesture indicates binding internal resolve
commitment to a course of action
instances.explanation: ‘Lifting the hand’ is again an idiomatic, metonymic description of swearing an oath, here regarding scattering.

deliberation: The phrase ‘their eyes were after the fetishes of their fathers’ uses ‘eyes’ metonymically for desire and focus of attention.

instances.english_text: and looked with longing to the fetishes of their ancestors (lit. ‘their eyes were after the idols of their fathers’)
target: the people’s desire and orientation toward ancestral idols
ground: where the eyes fix reveals what the heart desires
following with the eyes parallels following with the heart
instances.explanation: The ‘eyes’ are used metonymically for desire; their gaze ‘after’ idols expresses inner attachment.

deliberation: This difficult statement ‘I gave them statutes that were not good’ is best read as rhetorical irony or judicial handing-over language rather than a literal claim that God’s torah is evil.

instances.hebrew_text: וְגַם־אֲנִי֙ נָתַ֣תִּי לָהֶ֔ם חֻקִּ֖ים לֹ֣א טוֹבִ֑ים וּמִ֨שְׁפָּטִ֔ים לֹ֥א יִֽחְי֖וּ בָּהֶֽם
instances.english_text: Moreover, I gave them laws that were not good and rules by which they could not live
target: God’s judicial act of leaving Israel to destructive practices/laws
vehicle: speaking as though God Himself authored ‘not good’ statutes
shocking reversal of normal torah valuation
ground: emphasizes that what they embraced leads to death, not life
God’s ‘giving’ is letting them experience the results
instances.explanation: The verse uses ironic/judicial language, speaking as if God ‘gave’ bad laws, to express that He handed them over to destructive ordinances as punishment.

deliberation: Focused on ‘I defiled them by their gifts’ tied to child sacrifice. This uses the impurity metaphor: their sacrificial ‘gifts’ become a source of their own defilement.

instances.english_text: I defiled them by their very gifts
target: Israel’s moral and cultic ruination through child sacrifice
vehicle: ritual/tangible defilement resulting from contact with forbidden things
ground: their ‘gifts’ render them unclean before God
worship intended to honor becomes the source of contamination
instances.explanation: Their idolatrous ‘gifts’ are portrayed as defiling them, using impurity imagery to show how their worship corrupts them.

deliberation: Terms ‘affronted Me’ and ‘committed trespass’ use legal/covenant language in their standard senses. No distinct metaphorical image beyond normal treaty idiom.

Looked at ‘high hill,’ ‘leafy tree,’ and ‘pleasing odors.’ The locations are literal cult sites. ‘Pleasing odor’ is the main figurative sacrificial idiom, presenting sacrifices in terms of a fragrance that brings pleasure to a deity (here ironically misdirected).

instances.english_text: there they produced their pleasing odors
target: their sacrificial worship aimed at pleasing a deity
vehicle: fragrant smell rising and delighting someone
incense or aroma enjoyed by a person
ground: sacrifices are envisioned as giving pleasure like a sweet aroma to the recipient
posture: standard sacrificial metaphor here applied to idolatry
instances.explanation: Sacrifices are described as ‘pleasing odors,’ a metaphorical, anthropomorphic idiom in which deities are thought of as enjoying fragrance; here this language is applied to illegitimate worship.

deliberation: The verse exploits a pun between ‘bamah’ (high place) and ‘mah’ (what). This rhetorical wordplay is a figurative device, though not a metaphor in the strict sense.

instances.english_text: What is this shrine (bamah) that you visit? Therefore such a [shrine] is called bamah to this day
target: the idolatrous high places Israel frequents
ground: the similar sound invites a mocking question about the nature and worth of the place
instances.explanation: Ezekiel uses a pun between ‘bamah’ and ‘mah’ to question the very identity and legitimacy of the high-place shrines.

deliberation: Two figures: ‘in the way of your fathers’ (path metaphor for behavior), and especially ‘you are whoring after their detestable things,’ which uses sexual infidelity as a metaphor for idolatry.

instances.english_text: and go astray after their detestable things (lit. ‘you are whoring after their detestable things’)
target: Israel’s religious unfaithfulness in following idols
vehicle: a woman’s sexual promiscuity or prostitution
posture: strong metaphor depicting idolatry as spiritual adultery
instances.explanation: The verb ‘to whore’ is used metaphorically for idolatry, portraying Israel’s pursuit of other gods as sexual infidelity to YHWH.

deliberation: The child sacrifice reference is literal horror. The phrase ‘you defile yourselves’ reprises the impurity metaphor for idolatry. The repeated oath ‘I will not be inquired of by you’ is more of a speech act than an image.

instances.english_text: you defile yourselves with all your fetishes to this very day
target: their ongoing moral-spiritual corruption through idolatry
vehicle: ritual defilement by contact with unclean things
ground: idolatry makes them unfit for God like impurity excludes from holiness
inner degradation pictured as outward filth
instances.explanation: Idolatry is again portrayed as ‘defilement,’ extending cultic impurity language to describe their spiritual condition.

deliberation: Saw two main figures: (1) ‘what comes up upon your spirit’—an idiomatic metaphor for intentions/ideas arising in the inner person; (2) ‘serve wood and stone’—metonymy for idols as materials representing deities.

instances.english_text: And what you have in mind (lit. ‘what comes up upon your spirit’)
target: their inner plans and desires to be like the nations
vehicle: something rising up onto the ‘spirit’ like an object ascending
ground: plans and desires emerge into consciousness like something rising
instances.explanation: Thoughts and plans are depicted as ‘coming up upon the spirit,’ a metaphorical idiom for intentions arising within.

instances.english_text: worshiping wood and stone
vehicle: the raw materials (wood, stone) of which idols are made
ground: idols are materially nothing more than wood and stone
exposes the folly of treating lifeless materials as gods
posture: metonymic, implicitly derisive depiction of idolatry
instances.explanation: ‘Wood and stone’ stands metonymically for idols, underlining their lifeless material and mocking the idea of serving them.

deliberation: Key figures: ‘with a strong hand and an outstretched arm’ (anthropomorphic idiom for powerful intervention) and ‘with overflowing fury’ (anger as poured-out substance). I treat the arm-hand phrase and the anger phrase as two related but distinct images.

instances.english_text: with a strong hand and with an outstretched arm
target: God’s decisive exercise of power over Israel
vehicle: a powerful human hand and arm stretched out to act
ground: visible, effective power to act and control
instances.explanation: God’s intervention is depicted as that of a mighty person with a strong hand and an outstretched arm, an idiomatic metaphor for overwhelming power.

instances.english_text: and with overflowing fury (lit. ‘poured-out wrath’)
target: the intensity of God’s wrath in reigning over them
vehicle: wrath as a liquid poured out to overflowing
instances.explanation: God’s fury is described as ‘poured out,’ intensifying the picture of His reign as accompanied by overwhelming judgment.

deliberation: Reiterates the formula ‘with a strong hand, an outstretched arm, and poured-out wrath.’ Here I treat the clustered phrase as one composite metaphor for powerful, wrathful intervention.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּיָ֤ד חֲזָקָה֙ וּבִזְר֣וֹעַ נְטוּיָ֔ה וּבְחֵמָ֖ה שְׁפוּכָֽה
instances.english_text: With a strong hand and an outstretched arm and overflowing fury
target: God’s act of regathering Israel from the nations with decisive power and judgment
vehicle: a powerful figure using hand and arm, accompanied by poured-out anger like a deluge
physical might plus storm of wrath
instances.explanation: The repeated formula combines anthropomorphic power (‘hand/arm’) with the wrath-as-liquid image to depict God’s mighty, wrathful regathering.

deliberation: Two figures: ‘wilderness of the peoples’—a metaphorical designation of an exile/judgment setting among nations; and ‘face to face’ as an idiom for direct, unmediated encounter.

instances.english_text: into the wilderness of the peoples
target: the context of dispersion/exile and renewed judgment among foreign nations
ground: isolation, vulnerability, and testing like in a literal wilderness
posture: metaphorical extension of exodus ‘wilderness’ to exilic context
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘wilderness of the peoples’ depicts the exilic/judgment context among nations as a new symbolic wilderness where God will deal with Israel.

instances.english_text: face to face
target: the immediacy and directness of God’s judgment of Israel
vehicle: two persons physically confronting each other face to face
ground: openness, intensity, and inescapability of direct confrontation
instances.explanation: God’s judgment is said to occur ‘face to face,’ an idiomatic anthropomorphic metaphor for an immediate, unmediated encounter and reckoning.

deliberation: ‘Enter into judgment’ and ‘wilderness of the land of Egypt’ are straightforward in context, recalling past events. No additional distinct figurative expression beyond the already-noted wilderness motif in v.35.

Two strong metaphors: (1) ‘I will make you pass under the rod’—shepherd imagery for inspection and separation; (2) ‘I will bring you into the bond of the covenant’—covenant as a binding tether or fetter.

instances.english_text: I will make you pass under the shepherd’s staff
target: God’s examination and sorting of His people
vehicle: sheep passing under a shepherd’s rod for counting and inspection
ground: separation of acceptable from unacceptable animals
posture: shepherd metaphor for divine governance and judgment
instances.explanation: Passing ‘under the rod’ evokes a shepherd counting and inspecting sheep, a metaphor for God’s careful examination and sorting of His people.

instances.english_text: and I will bring you into the bond of the covenant
target: Israel’s renewed binding commitment to the covenant
vehicle: a physical bond, fetter, or yoke binding someone
ground: covenant imposes binding obligations like a physical bond restricts movement
posture: metaphor of covenant as a binding device
instances.explanation: The ‘bond of the covenant’ treats the covenant as a tether or fetter into which God will again bring His people, highlighting its binding force.

deliberation: Language of ‘purging’ rebels and not bringing them into the land functions in a literal judicial sense here. No separate metaphorical vehicles beyond legal removal.

Two aspects: the imperative ‘Go, each one, serve his idols’ has an ironic flavor—a rhetorical permission intended as condemnation; also ‘My holy name’ again metonymy for God’s reputation. The irony stands out as the main rhetorical figure.

instances.english_text: Go, every one of you, and worship your fetishes
vehicle: a permissive command seemingly granting them license to sin
ground: by ‘allowing’ what He condemns, God exposes their obstinacy
command form used to highlight futility and doom
irony between words and true will
instances.explanation: God’s command ‘go, serve your idols’ is ironic, not actual approval; it is a sarcastic exposure of their determination to continue in idolatry.

deliberation: ‘My holy mountain, lofty mount of Israel’ functions as a metonymy for Zion as the central worship site and for the restored community’s worship life. The mountain symbolizes the whole cultic reality.

instances.english_text: on My holy mountain, on the lofty mount of Israel
target: the restored center of YHWH worship and His dwelling with Israel
ground: height and holiness symbolize exalted status and nearness to God
mountain stands for the entire cultic complex and people gathered there
instances.explanation: ‘My holy mountain/the mount of Israel’ stands metonymically for Zion as the place and system of true worship in the restored future.

deliberation: The primary figure is ‘as a pleasing odor I will accept you,’ sacrificial aroma metaphor applied to the people themselves; also ‘I will be sanctified in you before the nations’ continues the reputation motif.

instances.english_text: I will accept you as a pleasing odor
target: God’s favorable acceptance of restored Israel
vehicle: a sweet, soothing fragrance brought near to someone
ground: acceptance and pleasure conceptualized as delight in fragrance
posture: positive sacrificial metaphor applied to people
instances.explanation: God says He will accept the people ‘as a pleasing odor,’ extending the sacrificial ‘pleasing aroma’ metaphor to express His restored delight in them.

deliberation: Describes being brought to the land sworn to their fathers; oath language ‘lifted my hand’ is implied from earlier, but not repeated explicitly here. No new figurative expressions in this verse alone.

Two path/purity metaphors: ‘your ways’ (derekh) for patterns of conduct, and ‘by which you defiled yourselves’ for moral impurity. The path metaphor (‘your ways’) is especially clear as a standard image.

instances.english_text: your ways and all the acts by which you defiled yourselves
target: Israel’s habitual behaviors and sinful acts
vehicle: ‘ways’ as paths one walks on; ‘defilement’ as impurity from contact with filth
ground: behavior is like a chosen path one travels
lifestyle results in a condition requiring cleansing
instances.explanation: Their ‘ways’ depict their conduct as a path they have walked, and ‘defiled yourselves’ again uses impurity language for their sins.

deliberation: Again ‘for My name’s sake’ is metonymy for acting for the sake of God’s reputation rather than according to their evil ways. This closes the unit with the same figure used earlier.

instances.english_text: for My name’s sake—not in accordance with your evil ways
target: God’s motive grounded in His own reputation and character
vehicle: ‘name’ as stand-in for character and reputation
ground: to act ‘for the name’ is to act to preserve one’s reputation
name encapsulates how He is known
contrast between their ways and His concern for His name
instances.explanation: ‘For My name’s sake’ again uses ‘name’ metonymically for God’s reputation, explaining that His gracious dealing is grounded in His own honor, not their merit.
